title: Lincoln Memorial and Reflecting Pool, Washington DC
address: 2 Lincoln Memorial Cir NW, Washington DC, DC 20037
review_list:
I’ve always had a great fondness for the Lincoln Memorial. I think it is the best monument in Washington. As you walk up the steps the incredible statue of Lincoln comes into view. It is awe inspiring. Simply fantastic. The words behind the statue are stirring and so very true: In this temple, as in the hearts of the people...


More  



This picture doesn't do this monument justice. I still can't believe that I was there. The steps were worth climbing although I was out of breath. I will have to revisit this monument. You will love it.

A place where history meets modern Washington DC. Unbelievably, a place where so much American history - swearing in ceremonies, MLK historic speech, Obama Swearing In Ceremony seats right in the center of DC life and politics.

Very important historical place, it's beautiful and a definite must see. Nearby are also Vietnam veteran memorial and Korean war veteran memorial, so you can see all three places at once. I highly reccomend visiting here.

I've seen the pool and memorial countless times on news film and movies, but to witness the area in person is a truly remarkable experience. There is an overwhelming feeling of being inside history and of standing at the heart of American democracy. The area is of course teeming with domestic and foreign visitors, but alone in one's head, one...


More  



I visited Lincoln Memorial in April 2015 both during night and during day time. The experience was different each time and equally thrilling. Night was peaceful with less people around so I could spend a relaxing time walking around the building and sitting on the steps. The next day late afternoon I chose to see it again and had a...


More  



It`s in one end of the National Mall. It`s a good way to finish the day. The lighting at nigh makes it even more interesting.

Larger than you imagine from the pictures! The climb up the stairs was the well worth it. The slide down the stone incline alongside the steps (not sure we were allowed to but it was so much fun) was even better!

Breathtaking. Absolutely breathtaking. As a visitor from Australia, I was struck with awe and reverence at the reflecting pool and statue of Lincoln. Slightly disappointed that I couldn't sit on Abe's knee for a photo, but I totally understand why.

This is a special place for me, I highly recommend the ranger guided tour, it was very informative and certainly enhanced my visit.

title: National Gallery of Art, Washington DC
address: 6th Street and Constitution Avenue, Washington DC, DC 20002
review_list:
I love this museum. It's relaxed and set up in an understandable way that even someone with casual interest can appreciate.

Excellent collection, free entrance, free audio-guide, amazing museum! Spend around 3hours to walk through it, stopping at your favorites!

Well displayed with construction information on some. Amazing likenesses to people one might know today even though the statues may be 2000 years old. Well worth seeing and using an audio guide if available.

Beautifully displayed and well-curated. Information is thorough but not overwhelming. If you enjoy Greek and Roman sculpture from about 350-30 BC, you'll love this.

Huge gallery of some of the greatest works in the world. I was constantly surprised finding work I had seen in books and hadn't realized that they were housed there. The musuem is very large and takes awhile to get though . It also has a great gift shop and some peaceful areas to rest.

I've visited all the top art museums in the world. Yes, there's not that many; and most charge for entry, and/or special exhibits. In this museum, because of the Mellon Family, I don't remember any fees of any kind for the forty plus years I've been coming to this place. There may have been something for King Tut; but that...


More  



You can spend an hour here or all day and feel like you've seen so much. It's a modern building with some very interesting features that will keep any age entertained.

My son and I have been to the NGA many times, but we still learn something new at each visit. Most recently, we saw the American Masters the 19th and early 20th centuries. Depictions of pristine countrysides and lakes by Thomas Cole and others transported us from the grey bleakness of winter Washington to sunnier (and less complex) places and...


More  



It's difficult to describe the collection at the NG because of the breath of the collection is so expansive. There are works to inspire absolutely everyone no matter your artistic preference. The NG is free to everyone so if you have the time I would split your visit into two days and visit a near by museum in the afternoon....


More  



If you are a classical art lover, then you are in heaven! this gem in the nation's capital give you all the thrill and so much more, from paintings, sculptures, wall hangings to all the little surprises, the building itself is a piece of art, prepare for a little time as you will need it! The east building is connected...


More

title: Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum, Washington DC
address: 6th and Independence Ave., SW, Washington DC, DC 20560
review_list:
The Air & Space Museum is a favorite spot for many of my out of town guests especially my nieces and nephew. You can spend all day there or enjoy an hour or so focusing on just one exhibit. There are interactive experiences in a number of locations. I've been to this museum at different times of the year and...


More  



I visited the museum with a Honor Flight group from Utah. It was interesting to listen about the planes from men who flew them. There were several bus loads of school children visiting also. This is a site you could visit several times and not see all that is there.

The museum has a fantastic collection of aircrafts and spacecrafts, and the exhibitions are very well set and quite exciting. It brought lots of childhood memories back!

Wow! Smithsonian does museums and all things relic excellently. We hoped between museums and the face they are free totally smashed us. Children would love the museum adventures in smaller doses. Will be back for sure.

This museum can be seen dozens of times without getting to understand everything we have done in space. This is both educational and interesting for any age group. It is free admission and gives you a rewarding experience. The museum store sells astronaut food which is gun for kids to have.

As a bit of an aero-head, I loved the Air and Space museum. All the history behind it was amazing and there was plenty of information readily available. More seating areas would have been great, but apart from that, a worthwhile visit for anybody who is interested in Air and Space travel.

Tremendous to see the history, to be able to go inside the planes and see the cockpits, to generally see history as it developed.

Wow, I thought this museum might be a little boring but I was so wrong. My son and I had the best time looking at the space shuttle and the history of flight. The museum is certainly geared towards kids but still fabulous for adults.

A fabulous museum with exhibits that appeal to all ages. A fascinating at the history of aviation from the beginning to beyond.

easily accessible, lotsof exhibits, not too many hands on for the little ones though. good complement to the Air and Space Museum in Dulles.

title: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington DC
address: 100 Raoul Wallenberg Plaza SW, Washington DC, DC 20024
review_list:
Each time I visit a holocaust museum, it makes me wonder how another human beings can be so hateful towards human beings to go to this extreme of dehumanization in tortures, causing extreme suffering from starvation and killings. Boggles my mind. Sooo sad!

This was a very heavy experience but so important to visit. If possible, I recommend breaking this up into two days. It is a lot to experience all at once. The Museum Cafe had adequate food but it was so expensive.

The Holocaust Museum has a dramatic, deeply touching exhibition about the worst genocide of the twentieth century. Unfortunately, history repeats itself, let's just have a look at the Bosnia war, the Ruanda genocide, and some other conflicts we have hardly heard about, however those cost hundreds of thousands of lives. That's why it is important to spread the words about...


More  



It is well put together, has some actual artifacts from Germany. But nothing that we haven`t seen or studied. I recommend if you are studying it in school and want to see more reality from the books. The message, not to forget about it is very good as well.

Plan on spending at least 2 hours here, but could be 3 or 4 hours. They have great displays which are very sobering and is an eye opening experience. I highly recommend visiting while in DC!

Very big and full of details. Take your time to see everything, but be warned it is a very "heavy" environment. Won´t regret going for a second, but I would make time to relax afterwards.

This place. Wow. I came in, ready to be moved, angered, saddened, and I was all that. But I also learned a great deal and realized how much I'd forgotten about the Holocaust--how it affected more than the Jewish people. I really paid attention to the part about complicity and how many "normal" people were complicit in genocide and made...


More  



A bit sombering but well done. Would recommend going earlier in day so you can decompress afterwards.

Very well-done museum following the time line of Nazi rise to power and the oppression and elimination - sometimes gradual, sometimes abruptly rapid - of the Jewish and other populations. It walks the visitor through the social and political history. It is dramatic and evocative on its own, presented without sentiment. It's worth the visit for us all to bear...


More  



A must for all to see. Can be very busy. But well organised. Very informative and well presented. Very moving and emotional. They have a unique presentation where you take the information of someone who suffered in the holocaust, and follow their story. Which brings the situation to life

title: Library of Congress, Washington DC
address: 101 Independence Ave SE, Washington DC, DC 20540
review_list:
The building preceding the Library per se is amazing, both the architecture and the exhibitions! The view to the Library you see from a top floor, through glass, but its worth anyway!

Get your Library of Congress card so that you can do research in the Reading Room. Explore the room and its symbols, including the beautiful mural gracing the ceiling.

We want to see the Magna Carta and found much more. The civil rights display was awesome. But the beauty of the library is truly a sight to see. The great reading room is so beautiful. But there are so many people on the tours that you need to bring a selfie stick to get any good pictures.

Other than all the books they have, the grand reading room is a gem by its own, a hidden secret in Washington; it's open, it's free, it's an architectural wonder! go and see it!

I was totally unprepared for the beauty of the building and the amazing amount of information available. The guided tour by the docents and the preliminary movie were both wonderful and very informative. A true MUST SEE

This is a beautiful building and I think a lot of people never think of going here. It is on the "hill" across from the capitol and down from the supreme court. It is worth the effort. The building is amazing inside.

I've been going there whenever I've time. I did research there for my genealogy project. The place is amazing.

The LOC is easily the most impressive building in all of DC. It seems like it really belongs in Europe, and it should. It is based on the very same opera house that is used in Phantom of the opera. The amount of details, from the different types of marble to dozens of murals, is staggering. Everywhere you turn there...


More  



The Library of Congress is one of the most beautiful buildings in Washington. It is really neat to walk to the library through the underground tunnel from the second floor of the Capitol Visitor Center.
Be sure to go to the third floor to look into the reading room!

Very ornate and well maintained gallery, but a somewhat odd collection of exhibits ranging from pre-Columbian artifacts to civil rights exhibitions. Sections which are open to the public are small and contained and you don't need much time here. I thought the standout areas were Jefferson's library and the view of the library of Congress.

title: Newseum, Washington DC
address: 555 Pennsylvania Ave., N.W., Washington DC, DC 20001
review_list:
Well worth the time and cost. Very interesting view of the news and how it was reported for various big events in the US/world. Great displays that allow anyone to take in as much as they want by use of lot of visuals, movies and interaction. We spent about 3 hours (2 adults, 2 college age children). Tickets are discounted...


More  



I avoids the news b/c quite frankly nothing good ever comes from it. It's one sad story after another after another. However, a friend had free tickets for the Newseum so I went, not gonna lie my curiosity was piqued. I must say, this museum is one of DC's national treasures. The exhibits are expansive, thorough, and moving. Though the...


More  



What a great place. Many floors of so much news. Past and Present. Great place to visit. Expensive ticket. But, this is an amazing museum. They are constantly changing to keep up with what is going on in the world today!

Another attraction that needs more than a few hours. Open, airy and plenty to keep ones interest....

As a former news director, I found the Newseum to be on-target, showing people what goes into news production and showing some of the subtleties and complexities of journalistic ethics. Even if you don't pay to enter the museum, one of its best parts is the sidewalk out front, where they post the front pages of the major newspaper in...


More  



This museum has news from all over the world. The exhibits are fantastic. They had Tim Russets office exactly how he left it, the lunch counter from North Carolina during segregation when the Students from A n T college were denied service. So many awesome photos from Hurricane Katrina. There's a sports exhibit . May sure you have plenty of...


More  



A truly wonderful museum devoted to the news in every aspect. Very informative videos on a wide variety of subject, and displays of newsworthy events covering a very broad time span. Great for students and history buffs of all ages.

Relatively new museum. Was surprised how interesting unique it was. Had a number of exhibits on the major stories over the last 100+ years. Also had several exhibits for children.

We were told my our Segway tour guide that the Newseum was among the top 5 places to go in DC, boy was he correct. We were so surprised on what we found. The museum is really well done. You get such a appreciation of the news, where we have come from, where we are going and the price of...


More  



Lots to see and learn. Great presentation and interactive displays but most importantly, how the first amendment lives and the people that uphold it everyday...
A place for the younger generation to appreciate the freedoms they have here...
Recommended visit... Plan at least a few hours.

title: Vietnam Veterans Memorial, Washington DC
address: 5 Henry Bacon Dr NW, Washington DC, DC 20242
review_list:
Open around the clock. Expect crowds and some emotions. It is deeply moving to see so many names, now lost from this war.

So much different than visiting the traveling Vietnam Memorial. This is a must visit site, to really feel the spirit of the place. Be careful with wheelchairs, the first part of the path is cobble stones, but then you get to the black granite.

We visited Washington in Feb and found the weather great for all the walking we were doing. My tip is to pack Snacks water and comfy walking shoes and map out a plan. It's all free and a wonderful experience to visit the memorials.

When you walk up to the memorial you can feel the emotion that it has. The thousands of names carved into the granite. Then there are small memorials that are left by the family and friends listed on the granite. It is one place that you will never forget.

I was deeply humbled by the memorial. A simply stunning, yet simple, way to remember those who served. A must see for any visitor to Washington.

As you walk upon it, the wall grows from inches tall to towering above you. You are struck by all of the names--so many that it's hard to even grasp. All dead. What moved me so deeply was seeing the grown men and women mourning their lost loved ones. Hands raised to touch a name as they cried. It made...


More  



We're 'fortunate' that we know NO names on this wall.
But as we are BOTH retired from the Navy with 50+ combined years of active duty, much of that time spent during the Vietnam War ... it saddens us that so many lives were so needlessly wasted.
We wonder when there will OTHER WALLS built to list the names of...


More  



This is one of the finest war memorials to be found anywhere in the world. For veteran or others who lived through the Vietnam era, or just someone with deep empathy, it can be a highly emotional visit. But it is well worth taking the time to do so. Designed by the architect Maya Lin, the monument is a black...


More  



A very moving and poignant monument to a difficult event in the history of the U.S. The volunteer guides were very good and as a place of reflection and tribute it certainly had an effect on my wife and I.

Been there many times. Always a memorable visit,
The Nam nurses memorial remote from main memorial. Had to ask guide for location. Although the wall is the main attraction, , the nurses deserve recognition also. A must see!

title: Korean War Veterans Memorial, Washington DC
address: 10 Daniel French Dr SW, Washington DC, DC 20001
review_list:
One thing I appreciate about the three war memorials (WWII, Viet Nam & Korean) is how visually different they are from each other. When I take friends and family we walk from one to the other. The soldier statues at the Korean memorial convey such emotion. The wall of images can keep my attention no matter how many times I've...


More  



We visited all the sites along this path late afternoon into the evening and found we felt safe and it was a lot less crowded. We simply got a taxi at the Jefferson memorial back to DuPont circle for dinner. Definitely a must do.

This monument to the Korean War Veterans is unique in it's design. A great way to honor those who served and died. Visit at night for a different view...

This monument has 19 scupltures representing soldiers from the Korean war. They are then reflected in off of a granite wall, making a total of 38 soldiers that represented the 38th parallel. There are also images etched on the wall. Very moving.

My father fought in the Korean War so seeing this memorial was very personal to me. He'd told me stories of people who had frozen to death. He told me about being hungry and exhausted. I see all that in this memorial--I've seen it before and will come back and see it again the next time I'm in Washington.

This is the most compelling Memorial on the Mall other than perhaps the Vietnam one. It is so haunting. Make sure you look at the granite wall with ether scenes and figures they are amazing. I visited when it had snowed and it is even more amazing. This is one not to miss. It's tucked away a little so please...


More  



To walk up and see the monument with the soldiers coming through the brush is beautiful. Korean War veterans are often forgotten and this monument was fabulous!

A large group of 7 foot sculptures depicting different branches of the armed forces. On patrol, they are haunting figures as they look around , as if at any moment they will be attacked. A parallel black granite wall with etched scenes and figures somewhat reflects these sculptures. I have seen photos of them in the snow and I can...


More  



..... and so tastefully done. Make sure you allow plenty of time for this as it's well taking time out and having a good look around.

The sculptures are a little chilling as you walk through the memorial. It was slightly raining the day I visited which added to that. These memorials are so important to remind us of the sacrifice of others. This is a must see.

title: National World War II Memorial, Washington DC
address: 17th Street NW, between Constitution and Independence Avenues, Washington DC, DC 20006
review_list:
Take your time to wonder through this site of memorial as you will need time to stop and reflect. We were here in February and found the water features empty but still really enjoyed the visit.

As somebody who has been to countless War Memorials across Australia and Europe, I was legitimately speechless at this memorial. It brought tears to my eyes to see all of the engagements and read the inscriptions around the memorial.

This was the first time I've seen this and didn't realize the fountains would not be running in winter. Duh. It's still magnificent, but had really been looking forward to seeing it lit up at night with the water. I'll have to come to DC when it warms up to see it in its full glory.

It is inspiring to see all the states listed and think what we owe to the Greatest Generation. It is a good place to take kids or even older young men and women so they can appreciate the sacrifices made for them.

We really enjoyed spending some time at the WWII memorial on the national mall. It's VERY large and really, you walk right thru it when you are going from the capital to the Lincoln Memorial. Please observe the signs to stay out of the fountain.

My son and I visited Washington DC for his college Fall Break. He is an avid WW2 history fanatic! When we arrived, he started going around and shaking hands and thanking all the veterans he could find. He said it was so sad that most of the veterans he talked to were Korean vets and that the WW2 vets are...


More  



There are 4048 gold stars on the Freedom Wall, one star for every 100 Americans that died in WWII. 4048 doesn't sound like all that much until you see them all together on the wall in front of you.
These memorials are so important to remind us of the sacrifice of others. This is a must see.

My dad was in World War II and I was happy to have the opportunity to see the memorial, particularly after seeing the Vietnam memorial which is incredibly moving. The WWII memorial seems like a memorial designed by committee. One section for the Atlantic, one for Pacific. A subsection for Normandy another for Battle of the Bulge. It seemed like...


More  



This memorial is respectful as well as informative and beautiful! It's really worth while spending a good amount of time here both at day and at night.

Visit this impeccably planned memorial. The scale matches the national and worldwide scope. The grandeur reflects our debt to the greatest generation. Stop by, reflect, and thank anyone over 80 you meet there.

title: Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial, Washington DC
address: Off West Basin Drive, Washington DC, DC 20242
review_list:
This stunning memorial invokes pride in all who see it, American born or not! It was worth the walk!

People don't often get across the water to see the other monuments, but they're actually my favorite. The MLK memorial leads into this memorial, and it's a beautiful walk. I've done it in all different seasons, and it's nice to see it at all times of the year. It's a walk through timeline of FDR's presidency. It has stunning views...


More  



We were here in Feb and it was cold. Later up for warmth. We walked all around the monuments in the late afternoon to evening and felt safe the area was well lit up in places and found many other people doing the same. We ended at the Jefferson memorial and got a taxi back to DuPont circle for $10.

This is a must see! A huge memorial that commemorates all four terms of his presidency. We had a tour there, so we got a little extra information about it. Being one of the most important presidents of the USA, this memorial gives him all the credits he deserve. Try to get some info about him to fully enjoy the...


More  



I walked through this memorial on 1/31/15. It is just a short distance from the National Mall and the Lincoln Memorial this memorial sits along the Tidal Basin and provides numerous benches to sit along the memorial and along the water. Walking through will take less than an hour but why rush; enjoy the surroundings.
The "rooms" of the memorial...


More  



Fantastic memorial, easy to find and in a beautiful location. We were the only people there, so it had an eery feeling to it which made it even more special. A great find, so glad we went.

The FDR Memorial was easy to walk and lovely to behold on an April afternoon during Cherry Blossom season. The statue of Roosevelt in a self designed wheel chair along with his wife, Eleanor's reflective thoughts on how it affected her husband's character make a great introduction to understanding the Roosevelt years.

This is one of the newer memorials and so worth the visit. Beautifully designed and peaceful. I was impressed with the added feature of Eleanor Roosevelt statue. Quotes from the former President are worth taking the time to read. I also loved Roosevelt's beloved Scottish Terrier being remembered with a statue---the kids visiting loved it too.

Didn't know about this but found it on the way to the National WWII Memorial. A fine tribute to one of the greatest presidents ever.

This memorial was one of the highlights of my trip. I'd been to DC before, but hadn't gotten to this one, as it's on the south side of the basin. So a big thanks to the Circulator bus, who have this as one of the their stops (for only $1) because I was surprised and impressed. It's definitely different from...


More

title: Jefferson Memorial, Washington DC
address: South of the Washington Monument on Ohio Dr., At the south shore of the Tidal Basin, Washington DC, DC 20242
review_list:
This monument was truly amazing and well worth the walk. Comfy shoes a must and in February we layered up as it gets chilly later in the afternoon even with all the walking. A true must.

Enjoyed a brief visit to Washington mainly to see the many attractions this city has to offer. This memorial was wonderful. Plan on at least a couple of days, 1 day is simply not enough. Will need to visit again!

The amount of history that held this place is amazing, you need to take enough time to walk through the museum inside. I also have the opportunity to take the night tour and also is worthy to invest sometime there.

It's a beautiful large space with a large statue of Jefferson in the center. I don't have great respect for Jefferson after reading the cover story about him in Smithsonian magazine.

The Jefferson Memorial is beautiful, like so many in DC are ....but this is one of my favorites. Its a little out of the way which makes it nice for a little change in pace. The last time we were there we were fortunate because the cherry blossoms were in full bloom. Absolutely gorgeous!!! I'm sure you will enjoy the...


More  



Another monument. Great for kids to learn about American history. As they see more, they wonted to learn and know more.

Very similar to the Lincoln Memorial on the outside, but tends to have less visitors, making it a more enjoyable experience to read the quotes on the walls and find out a bit about American history. Fantastic views from the steps and walking up to the monument along the river.

This memorial is really quite grand, with its spectacular columns and amazing view of the tidal basis. The inscriptions on the walls are thought provoking and relevant. I'd tack this memorial on after you see the FDR Memorial, the Vietnam, and the Lincoln (those are my favorites). It's particularly beautiful in the spring.

We only saw this memorial at night and it is quite beautiful across the water and up close.
The memorial needs a serious cleaning. Unfortunate it is not being taken care of.
4 walls of quotes, which were nice to see. The statue is quite large.

As you walk around the Tidal Basin you can't help but see the Jefferson Memorial. You ascend steps and there in front of you is the large statue of Jefferson. You can do two things at once by going during the bloom of the cherry blossoms. Usually early spring, but the season is short.

title: Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception, Washington DC
address: 400 Michigan Ave., NE, Washington DC, DC 20017-1566
review_list:
First time to the Basilica after passing it countless times over the years. This should be a stop for anyone visiting DC. The biggest Catholic church in N.America, & one of the 10th biggest churches in the world, the 30 minutes we spent there were not enough.Will definitely be going back

Went to televised Cardinal's Christmas mass. Major production. Full chorus, string orchestra, horn and organ pieces. A once in a lifetime event if you only make it once. Ample parking. Grotto visit also impressive.

A beautiful and stunning place to look at! I am local to Washington DC and every time I go there I still am in awe of how beautifully it was made and all the different colors and pictures to look at. If visiting or new to Washington DC, I would recommend a stop if you have time as it is...


More  



We always take our family and friends here when they come to town. It's a beautiful church to visit.

viewing from the outside, this is such a beautiful building. Once you enter the massive doors, words such as stunning, breathtaking, awe-inspiring are sublime...I have been in basilicas across the world in France, India, but none had me more spiritually awe stuck than tihis historic catholic shrine. The ceilings in each section are artistic masterpieces in themselves, and the lower...


More  



The best Catholic Cathedral of All America, with many chapel from different part of the word. The art, presented by the mosaics, statues representing Angels are amazing. A must SEE in Washington DC
A place of peace and confort of the spirit!!!

I would tell you to put religion aside for a bit and visit this beautiful building. The beauty is not only in the building itself but all that has been put inside as well. I would recommend a tour but will be honest there are times list but this is very sporadic as it's all done by volunteers, so that...

I have dozens of pictures from a few visits I've made over the years, but I'm not going to bother to post any as so many other people have just as beautiful shots, but a picture doesn't do it justice. Beautiful Church when you walk through the doors the sight of the altar, murals and ceilings are quite breathtaking. There is far more to the Church than just the altar, below is the crypt and other halls and rooms of religious importance. Well worth a visit.

I believe this is the largest Catholic church in the United States. It is a beautiful building sitting high on a hill within the confines of Catholic University. Visitors are welcome. In spite of its size, the gathering was very large. This might have something to do with the visit of Pope Francis the day before I got there.
There...


More

title: Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History, Washington DC
address: 10th Street and Constitution Ave, Washington DC, DC 20560
review_list:
LOVED! LOVED! LOVED! This museum is absolutely fantastic. A definite must for all ages. You can not miss this museum it's a free family friendly interactive Smithsonian you must see.

The Washington Natural History Museum was far superior in every way to the one found in New York. I could have spent hours upon hours exploring every corner of the museum. A must visit for any traveller to Washington.

While the exhibits and animals they had were extraordinary, it was super hard to see them or read any of the information. The crowds in August were crushing. So many people it was hard to walk around and definitely hard to get a feel for what was in the museum. We spent maybe 1 hour total and 15 minutes of...


More  



It's a good natural history museum but it's not the best (especially since so many of the exhibits we wanted to see - like the hope diamond - were closed). The fact that its free bumps it up from 3 stars to 4. The gift shops are great and you can get books on the exhibits you don't get to...


More  



My wife, adult daughter and myself visited here on the afternoon of Saturday Feb 6, 2016. My wife and I had been here before many years before but my daughter had never visited this museum. We spent a lot of time in the gems and mineral section, in the ocean section and in the human origins section. There were other...


More  



We know Smithsonian is the best, but our family does not love museums. We just couldnt get into it after a few hours.
The 1st flag was pretty cool to see.

A lot of the dinosaur bones and other things were reproductions and castings, but some of it was real. Definitely some cool things to see here, kids would especially love it!

There is so much to see, you can make a whole day out of it and still not have had enough time of you really want to get stuck in to it. Fantastic collections, worth a go whether a local or a tourist.

First of all, ALL the Smithsonian's are FREE!!!
This museum is perfect for all ages. There is something that will amaze you, intrigue you, teach you, and bring out the little kid and you. So much to do & see..... This visit is a no-brainer enjoy :-)

For a rainy day a good place to visit. The jewelry and stone department was astonishing.
For coffee and rest not too many places available. Poor service for coffee hungry,

title: Washington National Cathedral, Washington DC
address: Massachusetts and Wisconsin Aves. NW, Entrance on Wisconsin Ave., Washington DC, DC
review_list:
It`s new, inaugurated on the early 1990, the windows are beautiful! Specially when the light is right and the sun is shinning through them. There`s an elevator to the upper level of the tower, the view is very nice!

I rarely visit religious places, but was intrigued by the mention of the stained glass. Excellent local guide who knew all there was to know and told us the meaning behind the windows and made it all come to life.

The architecture of this building is just beautiful. I love to see churches every where I go and I never tire of coming back her. When we were at the vatican where is gives size compared to other churches around the world, it truly gives perspective. Must see in DC.

Come explore the beautiful grounds and gardens. Inside the cathedral enjoy beautiful works of art including sculpture, wood carving, mosaics, and over 200 stained glass windows. The top of the tower is the highest point in DC.
Sunday building access is free.
A seasonal highlight is the Handel's Messiah concert in December.

I've seen the building from the outside at night, but never inside. I was surprised how ornate and beautiful it is inside. title: Martin Luther King, Jr. Memorial, Washington DC

..... and of course a must do if in Washington. Much small er than we had expected but nice all the same. Nice walk down the avenue to reach here and not too much OTT security.

It's a must see for everyone! The history and awe for being in this special place is overwhelming. Write your senator and be sure to visit.

title: National Zoological Park, Washington DC

This zoo is spread out over rolling hills and quite a bit of acreage. Take your time and don't try to see it all or you'll be exhausted. I loved the cheetah exhibit - the male put on quite a show for us as he stretched out on a log and enjoyed the sun.

Don't forget to see the anteater.

Like all of the National Museums in DC, the zoo has free admission. On the other hand, parking is $22.

We were in DC the weekend after the big snow event, the zoo was open, paths cleaned and it was easy to move about. The down side was that a lot of the animals were not around. Even the bird house was lacking. The bird house is starting renovations so they have started to move the birds out. We were...

Single, Couples or Families are welcome at this place! Please remember to wear comfortable shoes. Don't forget to say hello to baby Bei Bei at the Asian Trail - Panda habitat. All ages will surely love this place and will help make great memories together! This attraction is free but there's a $$ to park - $22.00 currently might change.

The zoo is natural and low-key, with lots of paths. It wasn't crowded at all during winter break. The pandas and lions were very active. The only down side is they don't offer maps unless you pay $5. I love zoos, I love taking photos of animals, and we had a morning in DC to fill. We caught the bus from our hotel which was no hassle. title: Albert Einstein Memorial, Washington DC
address: 2101 Constitution Ave NW, Washington DC, DC 20418
review_list:
It would be silly to not stop at this memorial since there's no lines, no waiting! He was a great man with an amazing mind and accomplishments too numerous to count. Great photo ops with this genious

Never thought I would refer to Einstein as darling but this statue is darling. The kids can climb all over the great man. Worth the hunt to find.

He looks friendly. Take your pic with him but bring your own book 'cause they caught him lost in the capacious space of his own brain.

I love that this sculpture is a little off the beaten path being just beyond the main drag of the mall. it's in the shade with places to sit for contemplation. Only complaint is that all the kids get their pics taken on Einstein's lap, so it can be hard to enjoy with lots of people around.

We visit D.C. every November and always do an evening tour of the monuments (Lincoln, Vietnam, Korean). After the big three we cross Constitution Avenue so we can visit Albert. The kids like to climb up and get their pictures taken on the statue. It's free and fun!

Surprisingly large and easy to climb on. Close to the White House and just North of the reflecting pool and Vietnam memorial. Great tribute to Genius.

This is such a cool and interactive memorial! Albert will talk to you if you stand on a certain spot in front of him.

Not much to see here other than a giant bronze statue of Albert Einstein but it's a lovely statue and a fun thing to see and photograph if you are in the area... Just a 3 minute walk across the road from the Vietnam War Memorial and 5 minutes from the Lincoln Memorial site.

We went here after we visited Lincoln. It was just a small park near the corner. But it was a good site for kids. We could sit in his lap, and took a picture.
You can sit here for a while before yo go around.

I had no idea this existed, despite many visits to D.C. over the years. stumbled upon it with a friend. very small, but very well done.

make the effort.

Since the garden closed at 5, we headed over to the small museum/house since it's open until...

Dumbarton Oaks is great to visit any season but especially in Spring. The Byzantine collection is the best in the city and quite good.

The South American collection of art is beyond the best! What a little gem to spend the day at. The gardens are splendid.

I still have to wrap my mind around homes in large, developed urban areas -- even significant mansions such as this -- having gardens, and beautiful ones at that! Being here on a picture-perfect fall day really helps!
Don't mix up the gardens with the Library/Museum (or, for that matter, the house of the same name 8 blocks away). Treat...

Though Dumbarton Oaks is open only a certain time during the year, it's worth a visit. Stroll the lovely grounds, which will remind you of the English countryside, or take a tour of the house. I recommend checking online when it is open so you won't be disappointed.

This is quite large museum on different types of spy activities, both equipment and methods. Special attention is paid to real history of atomic bomb and imaginary story of James Bond. To my mind, the whole stuff is too old, at the level of 60ies, and urgently needs update with more recent materials.
update

Fascinating history and friendly staff, definately worth the price of admission. I'd recommend to all my friends.

title: U.S. National Arboretum, Washington DC

it was cool to see, but wouldn't spend a day of it, it was pretty though and cool to take pictures at

There is a train display during the holidays which is a great thing to bring the kids to. We can't get there every year but even just going once is worth the visit.

We loved the Arboretum. A wide variety of vegetation, great walking trails. Just a beautiful place to spend a couple of hours outside on a nice day.

title: U.S. Capitol Visitor Center, Washington DC

review_list:

Son and his fiancé were in town, and we decided to go to the Visitor Center. It was awesome. Extremely interesting and lots of historical knowledge.

If you do not have a reserved ticket it is easy to get one without much delay in the visitor center. The tour of the Capitol is one of my all time favorite tours. To view the senate and congress sections you must obtain tickets ahead of time from your state representatives

What was particularly fascinating was the displays on how government should work (!) as well as the building of the Capitol itself. Well worth a return visit.

The capitol was amazing with so many insights that you would miss going by yourself. Our Senate office arranged for our tour and we got to see many fun and interesting things.

"Wonder" is an art display using everyday materials in exciting and creative displays. Some of the items used are marbles, thread, lights, tires, wood pieces and bugs. Don't miss the Wonder Exhibit at the Renwick. It features exhibits by nine artists and most of the exhibits will be there until June. One room features a "rainbow" created with thin threads. The sculptures re unique. Make sure to watch the 10 minute video before viewing the exhibit.

Having been to DC many times before and only seeing the monuments and the natural history museum I did a little research before my trip this time. We hoped for much more. The introductory movie is choppy, outdated, and really pretty bad. The standard exhibits are mostly flat panels with surprisingly few artifacts. Interesting history and artifacts. Visited when it first opened so it's been a while. There have probably been many new additions. Worth the visit.

This is apparently the newest Museum on the mall so it is quite clean and airy. We visited this museum due to all the other museums being overcrowded. We were glad we did. So much to learn about the Native Americans. The exhibits were great, the video drew you in with video above and below you. the interactive part was great too. Highly recommended

thoroughly enjoyed this museum. My husband's grandparents were American indian and it was really interesting to see so much history on the subject. The exhibit is very sad and poignant I had no idea how much incredible suffering went on.

We toured D.C. beginning on the 26th of December and this was one of the stops I wanted to make. A local friend said she had done the tour long back and it was so boring. Her friend said that that was a long time ago and the tours have stepped it up a notch so naturally I wanted to...

One of the great attractions for adults and kids. See your money printed before it goes through your hand and is taxed and returned to Washington. Its a lot of fun to watch them make your money!

Good tour shows the process of making bills. Very interesting to see the process would recommend. Gift shop offers many money related items.

title: Vietnam Women's Memorial, Washington DC
address: Washington DC, DC
review_list:
Beautifully done, do not miss this and the description by the path of the women who served in this war. It is near the Vietnam memorial.

Located in the same general vicinity as The Vietnam Veterans Memorial Wall this is a tremendous statue you will wish to look over ... Be sure to walk all around to experience and appreciate the great detail throughout ... This is also particularly effective at nighttime due to the lighting ... You will not be disappointed.

Was pleasantly surprised by this sculpture. We didn't know it existed but came across it while walking around. Take a moment to really look at all the women, very dramatic.

While viewing this memorial, you really start to think about the lives and sacrifices of the women that made a difference in the lives of so many during the war.

Definitely worth taking time to see this memorial to the women who served and helped (mainly nurses). This memorial was well done and a beautiful and touching piece of art.

While at the Vietnam Wall, you really need to see this statue dedicated to all the women (mainly nurses) that were in this war.

I have a particular attachment to this memorial because my friend drew it in our art class years back, and she did a gorgeous likeness. But nothing compares to seeing it in person. Coupled with the Wall, it's a clear message that absolutely no one went untouched by the sadness of Vietnam.

This stunning piece of sculpture is right by the Vietnam War Memorial (a 1 to 2 minute walk away) and is worth a quick look and a photo when in the area.

This memorial, very close to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, is a beautiful and inspirational tribute to all of the thousands of army nurses who helped care for the terribly high casualties inflicted upon our soldiers during the Vietnam War. It captures the bravery and dedication of these courageos women who were so necessary to the war effort.

This sculpture, close to the Vietnam Memorial, is a touching depiction of the women who with their own blood, sweat and tears fought to save the lives of our American soldiers.

title: Rock Creek Park, Washington DC

It is also a little scary as it darkens in the afternoon. We live within walking distance, and I take our dog there. It's nice...

I love this place. This is the standard for what a city park should be. There are wild forests and walking trails removed from the sight for sound of the city. There are places to enjoy a bike ride. More  



A lovely natural area that is a welcome escape from the hustle and bustle of DC. Nice trees, rivers and streams...

Great place for taking a walk away from everything else in town, we stayed very close and went on a couple of days just for the peace and quiet

Here is a nice green oasis from the concrete and busy nation's capital.
There is easy access from many points in northwest D.C. (including the national Zoo). The park meanders through much of the northwest quadrant.
It's verdant and refreshing. There are always many people bicycling and jogging (and to my regret, we did neither).

Taking some time from the heavy traffic and noisy downtown is like a breadth of fresh air. This renown passage through several miles of forest and spots to park, hike, or picnic is a wonderful attribute in DC. Pick it up from Independence Ave along the Potomac and follow Bridge Street for starters

Close to the Zoo and has everything form running tracks to zip lining - you could get lost in here for the day.

had a great time here today with my family.
a really interesting worthwhile visit.
historic, and entertaining.

title: National Museum of Women in the Arts, Washington DC
address: 1250 New York Avenue NW, Washington DC, DC 20005
review_list:
Pleasantly surprised to find this museum is open to all free of charge on the first Sunday of the month. The exhibit PATHMAKERS was a delightful mix of art, design, and crafts by women of the world. I also thoroughly enjoy the file on Eva Zeisel which was 1 hour in length. The staff was marvelous and very helpful.

We just happened to catch this museum on their one free day a month – the first Sunday of every month. That certainly was a bonus for us. The museum is housed in a former Masonic Temple and has been opened since 1987. This museum is dedicated strictly to women artists – such a nice change. The ground floor still...


More  



We loved the permanent collections as well as the temporary works of art that were there. I highly recommend this museum to everyone. Will definitely go back!

We attended a wedding at the Museum of Women in the Arts. Absolutely stunning. It's a beautiful building.

Simply gorgeous. Cocktail hour amongst priceless works of art. Dinner and dancing were on separate floors, but it didn't seem to have an impact. One of the most beautiful wedding venues I have been to.

Tough this museum is not a part of the Smithsonian and therefore you have to pay entry, I found it to be worthwhile. The art was well curated and, in part, quite well known. I would definitely suggest not overlooking this smaller museum in downtown DC.

There's nothing much here to see. It's an embarrassment to women in the arts. Perhaps if they have a major exhibit it may be worth your time and money. Otherwise, skip it! You will see much better examples of the best artists for free at the National Gallery.

Attended a function at this museum for the holidays and was very impressed. Beautiful museum, wonderful location for a corporate function.

Situated in the heart of DC (steps from Metro Center), small and very pleasant place to visit. The collection includes the art from the 16th century up to present. This is a unique museum dedicated to women's art achievements.

My wife and I attended a gala at this museum. We were surprised and amazed at how many women were highly talented artists over the years. Because we had barely an hour before dinner, we were only able to explore one floor. The museum definitely deserves more time for a careful exploration.

We attended the Auto Show and were surprised at the condition of this convention center. Also, although the car show opened at 9:00 a.m. and the food stands were staffed with food, they were not permitted to sell any food until 11:00 a.m.? Lots of disappointed attendees.

My husband and I were recently in DC for the American Dental Association meeting, and spent three days here taking CE classes. We go to the meeting each year so we’ve seen a lot of different venues, and this is pretty standard as far as convention centers go.
The ADA provided busses at host hotels to get attendees to the...


More  



I went recently there for the American Dental Association Meeting. The center is within walking distance of dozens of hotels, shops, restaurants and bars. HUGE meeting space with everything you need.

I've been to a lot of convention centers over several years. This one ranks on the better side. Plenty of individual class rooms. Very large exhibit space available. Several convenient restrooms, although some are small er than needed. Corridors are generally wide enough to navigate around the crowds. Enjoyable experience.

Very generic convention center. Lots of space but very plain. Nothing DC about it. The staff here were constantly yelling at everyone to show their convention badges. Convenient to the Metro and lot of hotels. Restrooms were relatively clean. Women's room often had lines.

Attended a pediatric conference here and found the venue easy to get around, well marked for those numerous room changes. Unlike some enormous centers which have all the visual appeal of an airplane hanger, the architecture works with its purpose and there are plenty of places to sit in between events.

We were an exhibitor for a trade show at Walter E. Washington. The staff were really very helpful. Union workers, that in other cities might be a bit gruff, were terrific and friendly. The amenities are very good. What is also nice is that the location is great. It's right downtown and you are only a short walk away from...


More  



Was in town for an event and although the place was huge, everything was well marked and they had a very efficient way of getting people around since there were also other events going on.

Walter E. Washington Convention Center is a great facility for hosting any meeting. the facilities and the surrounding, shopping, restaurants, and hotel package is more that good!

This is a great location for a trade show, I've been to the annual Army trade show for years and the venue flows well and offers plenty of choices for food.

title: The Kreeger Museum, Washington DC
address: Washington DC, DC
review_list:
This is now so much easier to both get to and to depart because of uber. In a beautiful section of DC, with beautiful homes, this austere executive manse was designed by Philip Johnson. Has some wonderful paintings and sculpture, indoors and out.

Very good collection of impressionist and modern artists: Monet, Renoir, Van Gogh, Chagall, Picasso, Mondrian, Degas, Gorky, Braque. The building is of interesting architectural design, access to the exterior of the building and the sculpture garden included in the admission. Free parking. They conduct tours every hour or so at no extra charge. The tour takes about an hour.

This is a a superb private, extremely well curated collection. About 25 minutes by bus from downtown, it is well worth the visit if you love modern art and the impressionists. There is also a small outdoor sculpture display. Open on weekends. Note that Dunbarton Oaks is on the same bus route and could combine to make a excursion.

Great little place. Need reservations, $10 adult, $7 student. Guided tour through a converted residence.
Wonderful selection of art including; Monet, Van Gough, Renoir, Picasso artwork. Also a very nice assortment of sculpture work.
Tour guide very informative and knowledgeable.
Take a Uber from DC ($11) and the tour lasts about 2 hours.
Recommend highly.

I went with family to do something different when in town for a wedding. The location is kind of hard to find with the GPS. It was ten dollars per adult, and well worth it. I was able to see fine art and sculptures up close. The fountains outside were beautiful. It does not take long to see all the...


More  



It's good to be the king. Mr. Kreeger made lots of money but he knew how to spend it. The museum building, the former Kreeger family residence designed by Philip Johnson, is itself worth the visit. The collection of paintings from Picasso, Braque, Cesanne and many others is outstanding. Strolling through the museum and it's garden on a bright fall...


More  



Hmmmm. I don't usually like to dis a cultural institution that's trying but my biggest takeaway from my visit here is that the great art in DC came from elsewhere and while there was local interest in art, it never reached the level of sophistication of New York, Chicago or Los Angeles.
It's not a surprise that some of the...


More  



Wander amongst Monet and May Ray masterpieces in the most comfortable of settings. Wonderful sculpture garden. Great cocktail parties from time to time as well!

Nice layout, interesting art and artifacts, good restrooms, friendly staff, comfort to take your time

The Kreeger Museum offers a striking collection of beautifully curated art by names you will instantly recognize. The have work by Monet, Renoir, Pissaro, Sisley, and a staggering number of Picassos. These are not sketches or weak work either, but strong, interesting pieces any art lover should take in.
The fee is $10, but there are student/senior discounts available. Also,...

We didn't actually realize we were at the Navy Memorial until I looked at our map and went, "Wait hold up." *looks around* "Uh guys, that lovely fountain there is the Navy Memorial." Great memorial, every Tuesday evening in the summer the navy band will play for a couple of hours! If you can time it for Veteran's day or Memorial day the event and band are even better!

I attended a conference in this attractive facility and had no idea what it had to offer. It was fascinating to read the various plaques and exhibits and the staff was very helpful. The shop was loaded with Navy "must haves" if you're a fan of the service.

We were walking to a metro station after dinner when we happened upon this lovely memorial. I guess I would call it a "hidden treasure," because it's nowhere near the war memorials as I would have expected it to be. The centerpiece is a statue of a sailor, one of several placed in various cities. It's a homecoming statue -...


More  



I did not enjoy this. Not because the Navy isn't important but because the people who organized this don't seem to understand the importance of the Navy. This presents as a bunch of exhibits without a common theme or narrative linking them together. It is like they stuck some Navy stuff in some rooms without an intelligent design. The Navy...


More  



The Navy memorial has a lot going for it. It is large and open and easily accessible while on your way to and from other attractions. The highlight is the famous "lone sailor" statue, but there are also art representations of every speciality group in the Navy. Inside the heritage center is the "homecoming" statue, a tribute to Navy families....

Located along Pennsylvania Avenue and 6th Street (across from the National Archives), this Memorial is easy to find. It has beautiful fountains, flagpoles, and several sculptures depicting the contributions of the US Navy. Please refer to the attached pictures.
Due to time constraints, I did not have time to visit the Heritage Center. I plan to visit it next time...


More  



Nice place to hang out and take a rest. Cool to see the plaques depicting different Navy events. Take a picture of with the shipman who represents those who have served, those who are currently serving, and those who will serve.

Nice place if you're walking around Pennsylvania Avenue, between the white house and the national archives. There are some statues and plaques commemorating mostly civil war heroes. Not worth a detour though.

This small museum has lots of small model ships and a handful of displays. It's not a big museum, and really is gauged more toward former Navy personnel than casual visitors. There is a spot where you can look up old shipmates.

title: Old Stone House, Washington DC
address: 3051 M St Northwest, Washington DC, DC 20007
review_list:
A nice stop along a busy commercial street...to see some history. It only took a few minutes to read some interesting history and look around a few rooms. I recommend it for anyone. A glimpse into the past!

The oldest house in Washington with a great history and some myths as well. It doesn't take long to do the self guided tour and is well worth spending 10 minutes in.

A great way to see the oldest house in Washington plus free entry with a
Nice gift shop attached no queues, very interesting. Would highly recommend this

Built in 1765, this year marks the 250th birthday of Washington DC's oldest surviving house. Under the 'care' of the National Parks Services, the house and its small garden outside look kept in good nick. Because it's really quite small, one could easily walk past the house on the street without realising its significance. But it's good for a very...


More  



As we struggled along Georgetown's busy M Street on a pleasant Saturday afternoon, we almost missed this gem : a neatly restored two-story cottage which apparently pre-dates the American Revolution, and is now managed by the National Park Service.
Built in 1765 - making it Washington's oldest building - it seems to have had a chequered history since then, allegedly...


More  



There's not an awful lot to see but what there is is interesting and the lovely garden at the back provides a pleasant place to rest for a while. Certainly go if you are in the area.

This is a cute little home that's the oldest property still standing in Washington DC. It's been turned into a museum with free admission so it's worth a stop if you're in the Georgetown area and have a few minutes to spare. Just keep your expectations low because there isn't a lot of info or much to see. It has...


More  



Great to run in and run through. Not a lot to learn, but a good experience. Park Service staff pleasant.

The house is nice although sometimes when we come it seems to be closed. The garden in the back is a gem. You can rest and maybe eat a treat bought from nearby dessert shops. Worth a stop if you're in Georgetown.

It was not yet opened when I passed by this attraction on September 26, 2015 as I walked along M Street. I went back after visiting other attractions of Georgetown.
It opens at 11: 00 a.m. and closes at 6:00 p.m. from Wednesday to Sunday. (Please see related picture). Entrance is FREE. There is a small Gift Shop and a...

title: Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle, Washington DC
address: 1725 Rhode Island Ave NW, Washington DC, DC 20036
review_list:
This small cathedral is situated on Rhode Island Avenue not far from the Australian Embassy. From the outside it doesn't look like much, but once you go inside, it is filled with plenty of pews and soaring mosaics that stretch across the ceilings. The altar area is breath-taking and the clergy, welcoming to visitors. The only negative is that people...


More  



St. Matthew's easily rivals the splendor of many of the best European churches. St. Matthew is the patron saint of civil servants so the church recognizes all those who work in governmental service. The church has hosted many famous events. The funeral mass of President John F. Kennedy was celebrated here on November 25, 1963 and is commemorated with an...


More  



St. Matthew's is physically a beautiful church, mosaics and light diffusing marble (?) windows. But the best part was the friendliness of the priests and parishioners and the wonderful homily and music. I wish I'd had time to go to the afternoon tour to learn more about it.

This cathedral is worth a visit to if you enjoy European-style architecture and are in the area. You can just walk around and leave or sit in a pew and reflect. It is a piece of old-era beauty in a modern city.

This church quickly evokes strong feelings - as soon as you see the plaque at the entrance that it was here where JFK had his funeral, you will recall the moving picture of Jackie and the two small children standing on the steps. Today this is of course a living, working, worshiping Catholic church, but memories of this occasion over...


More  



Home of the Cardinal, you'll occasionally catch him for Mass. But in general, this is a nice parish, friendly and welcoming people with good music. The cathedral itself is a nice place: they seem to have cornered the market on marble. The mosaics are lovely.

This is more of a church than a cathedral. It is not worth going out of the way to visit, while it is a lovely place of worship.

This cathedral has some byzantine elements but it is mostly neo-romanesque and I think it was built in the late 1800s. Several important people's funeral were hel here including president Kennedy and Philippine President Quezon.

This is a beautiful cathedral it was right near our hotel and a easy metro ride you have to get off at Dupont Circle Metro Station or Farragut North Metro Station Must Do in DC

This is the church that was the site of the funeral of President John F. Kennedy. It is a place of reverence and reflection.

Surely loved this theater setting for a great show. Talent amazing and our seats felt so close. Only problem was long lines to 2nd floor concessions and restrooms which seemed poorly staffed for the crowd. But the show made up for it!

Another interesting place to see in the DC area. This is one of those places not necessarily to see 1st but on the secondary list. It is worth a visit.

My friend and I went to see Cinderella here. I had bought the tickets on line for the wrong time and the box office did an awesome job exchanging them. The theater is very nice and historic. Took the wife to Cinderella for her birthday. Been to the National previously for Stomp where we sat in the Orchestra seats. This time we sat in the Mezzanine in the 6th row. We were so pleased to see Angela Lansbury in "Blithe Spirit" at the National Theatre. Charming Theatre, wonderful play and Angela Lansbury was at her stage best.

We saw Newsies here in June. The theatre looks wonderful and the sightlines from the balcony are excellent. A true classic restored!

title: United States Department of the Treasury, Washington DC

review_list:
We could only view the grandeur of the building from outside as it appeared to be closed. That would make sense since it was Christmas vacation. It’s still worth a look and some pics. My friend said they usually have tours and it’s pretty interesting.

Another secondary venue to see it the DC area, learn about what Hamilton was thinking when he set up this part of our government

It looks good, the same as other nearby buildings in the area. Perhaps it is worth a few minutes of photo-taking here? I don't know if it goes the same as you though.

One of the more impressive buildings due to its size. Dont know whether you can do a tour but worth a quick photo, not least with it being next door to the White House

This was a surprisingly cool tour. This isn't where they make the money though, that is the Bureau of Engraving (which was very interesting). The tour is free which is always good. You just have to contact your representative or their staff and they will help you get it set up.

This is a building where locals and tourist pass by it without and afterthought. It's a large building but it is shadowed by its more prestigious neighbor...the White House. truly a fascinating and learning experience to see how money is actually made and DESTROYED, GREAT FOR CHILDREN,

Nice location next to the white house. Once I went inside to the library and had the opportunity to do some research there. It wasn't that special except I got to see the old board room which is really impressive.

My wife and I passed the U.S. Treasury Department while passing from the White House to Old Ebbitt Grill. This is a place for the whole family --(children should be a little older to get something out of it).

It's wonderful that it has been preserved amidst the modern buildings - even looks a bit gloomy from the outside. You have to join a...

My daughter was married in the beautiful solarium of the Heurich House in late August. It was a very unique venue for a wedding with its exquisite stained glass windows and period furnishings. The daughters of the Heurich family were married in the mansion and it is now available for rental.
From the moment you enter the castle, you are...


More  



This museum was close to our hotel. You can only see it by taking a docent tour. Suggested donation $5. Lots of local history here and a nice treat.

This museum was not even a block away from our hotel. It was a rainy day and we weren't interested in anymore cab rides or a lot of walking, so we signed up for the last tour of the afternoon on a Saturday. We are SO glad we did. The story of the Heurich family is interesting but the best part of this museum is the house itself. It was ahead of its time technologically and it's interesting to see/hear about. The Heurich House is one of the best preserved / restored high Victorian mansions I have seen. Beautiful house and a knowledgeable tour guide. Our guide chose just the right details to share about every room of the house including background about how the house was built and the family.

When it was built, this extraordinary home was ultra-modern with many interesting innovations. Because it remains family owned, it still features almost all of the original furnishings, light fixtures, etc. The level of detail in millwork, mosaics, ceiling painting, etc. is absolutely extraordinary. Guides are knowledgable and passionate which makes touring this house even more enjoyable. Definitely worth a visit!

This house has been beautifully preserved, including a lot of the original furniture, which is rare. Tour group was very small, felt almost private. I love touring old houses, and this one by far was quite unique in both architecture and the home environment. title: Corcoran Gallery of Art, Washington DC
address: 500 17th St. NW, Washington DC, DC 20006
review_list:
Neat clean but in no way as fascinating as many of the other art galleries available to view. Pass if you are short on time.

One of the best museums in the entire area. Many events held here also so a trip back in the evening to see the who's who is also a treat. Hope you make it soon!,

How many art galleries are there in D.C.? I have no idea. I did enjoy the Corcoran Gallery. There is some excellent art there.

NEXT is the Corcoran students senior thesis work. It is on display until May 17th. You may be viewing work from the "NEXT" big named artist. These students had worked very hard on their projects. It is inspiring to see their work displayed on the galley walls.

We visited this beautiful building near the White House earlier this year because it is one of the few attractions in DC we had not seen and it was rumored to be closing soon to prepare for a transition of its collection to the National Gallery of Art. The last weekend at the Corcoran was bittersweet but also a freebie . The guards were all a bit sad but willing to talk about the upcoming changes. Too bad it is gone forever

More  



For a very short while only, this gallery is free, before it reopens (when?) under the auspices of the National Gallery of Art. See the original collection while you can. There are some iconic paintings here. Go.

This is a unique art gallery with an incredible collection that includes two Gilbert Stuart Washington portraits and stunning art from the 12th Century to the present. Since the Smithsonian has taken over there is no longer any admission fee. You have to hurry as the Corcoran is closing On October 1, 2014 for a three year rennovation.

Well worth the visit before it closes. Nice building. Can't wait to see what it looks like after the renovation.

On a recent visit to DC we walked from our hotel on 15th street to the neighborhood of Adams Morgan (18th street area). It's colorful, vibrant and full of cafes, bars & restaurants. Well worth the walk to get away from the Capitol Hill feel to the funky neighborhood vibe.

We spend a sunny evening in this beautiful area on my first day in DC. The weather was so warm for an October evening that we eat outside.
We enjoyed quite a lot this place because of the architecture, the atmosphere and the variety of restaurants and bars.
A place to see!

This area is jammed packed with great food, drinks, and music! I recommend looking up happy hour menus if you are on a budget. I will also note that this is a safe area to walk around at all hours.

This is a great area in DC and I always enjoy stopping by when I am over in DC to visit my cousin. Enjoy :-)

This is a fantastic neighborhood. Plenty of restaurants and a few independent shops. Madams Organ is a must!! A real DC institution. On almost any given night there is live music of some genre sparking a vibe that is unmatched on the entire strip. Hope you make it soon

A great neighborhood in DC with lots of restaurants and bars. Biggest frustration with this area is parking - so I recommend taking an über or taxi.

We walked all overs Adams Morgan on a Saturday afternoon, and there are several great restaurants and shops. But this area is really all about the nightlife, with pubs and music. I would say perfect for those in their 20s and 30s looking for a fun night out. Not so much for families with kids.

This is a great place to meet upnwith friends. It's got great late 19th and early 20th architecture, and there are so many awesome restaurants here. Certainly worth a stop!

Beautifully restored architecture, vibrant colors, clean. We attended a play, and the sound and lighting were perfect. Bathrooms clean and spacious. Very friendly staff. I will definitely return.

A lovely setting for wedding pictures. Quite busy with wedding photos. It seemed a bit disrespectful to the soldiers of DC.

Some people don't take the time to stop by this memorial because they are not sure what it represents. We took the time to stop by. The memorial is in need of a good cleaning .

Great place to pick up your gifts to take home and they have a photo ops area where you can take a picture like your in the Oval Office.

Great restaurants with a high density, lots of people and places to visit. Lots of people. Tourists and regulars, lots of hubbub. Good shopping. Good eating. Nice place to hang.

This is the part of DC you see in TV and movies--between the Capitol and the White House. I love walking down America's main street! There are some great sites and restaurants here, too, so enjoy it and take your time, stop for coffee or a meal!

It is the main route for Presidential Inaugural Parades. It links the White House to the Capital. You will notice since 9/11 Pennsylvania Avenue is now blocked of at the White House

Informally designated Penn Quarter, this is actually a small arena filled with restaurants and shops situated about half-way between the White House and Capitol Hill on Pennsylvania Avenue. The Navy Memorial anchors the north side of the street with the Archives on the south side. The stairs and escalators from the Archives Metro stop feed up into the area. Some...

This area is basically a business district: it is full on weekdays, especially lunch hour but empty on weekends except for tourists.
There are a few good restaurants (Rasika and Central come to mind, check my reviews).
There are too many homeless as usual for DC...

Penn Quarter is a great place to stay in DC! Abundance of Hotels, Shopping, Dinning, and Places Of Interest just within walking distance!

title: National City Christian Church, Washington DC
address: 5 Thomas Circle, Washington DC, DC 20005
review_list:
You would never guess the interest in this church but first you'll have to find the way in! This is on the east side along the sidewalk. It's best to find out for yourself rather than me telling you but part of it is Presidential. We had a fascinating personal tour.

14th Street is now the place to go it seems in DC. And right where the more lively side of the street starts there sits this church in the huge Thomas circle. They have a lot of services and do a great job at helping the community.

This church is quite grand and lovely from the architecture on the outside, and they seem to be an active part of the community. There were people exercising as a group outside this morning! It's also situated nicely at a large circle, too, so it's an easy landmark to spot!

We stopped by there last week while heading to the National Cathedral. This place is very peaceful and very beautiful. It is nothing like the Cathedral, but is is very quaint and well designed.

The church's architecture is beyond beautiful; it is a masterpiece. JT M noted in his review two famous other works by John Russell Pope, the architect: The Jefferson Memorial and the National Archives. Besides those there are also in Washington The Brazilian Embassy Residence on Massachusetts Avenue, the Temple of the Scottish Rite on 16th Street and Pope's all time...


More  



This church was designed by the same architect who designed the Jefferson Memorial and the National Archives. Beautiful architecture and stained glass. This is one of my favorite churches in DC.

I been there twice for Christmas concerts. Great customer service, beautiful church and best of all the acoustic is amazing.

title: D.C. Fire and EMS Museum, Washington DC

review_list:
Call ahead and you won't be disappointed. It's a functioning Fire House and the guys on duty were great. An incredible museum to learn about DC Fire Fighting. Jim hit the highlights and we walked away with a great appreciation for the DC Fire and EMS services.

The Friends of the Fire Station does great things for the community - education for the adults and children as well as providing outstanding support for the Fire Service. Thank you Walter, you made our day!

This is a brilliant little specialty museum focused on the history of fire fighting in Washington DC in particular, but including things from further afield.
